title: Coca-Cola, Kellogg respond to Brady's remarks
text:
Coca-Cola on Tom Brady's 'poison' remark: 'All our drinks are safe' By John Breech 
Despite what Tom Brady said on Monday, Coca-Cola would like you to know that its beverages are not " poison for your kids ." 
The latest from SportsLine Power Ratings: Broncos heading in wrong direction 
Brady made the comment during a lengthy conversation with WEEI-FM in Boston on Monday that revolved around Brady's personal trainer, Alex Guerrero. 
Guerrero's been under fire since the weekend when a scathing article was published that highlighted the trainer's troublesome past. 
The quarterback's point was that he doesn't care if people disagree with his personal trainer's methods because the people who disagree are the same people who are putting junk in their body. 
"You'll probably go out and drink Coca-Cola and think, 'Oh yeah, that's no problem.' Why? Because they pay lots of money for advertisements to think that you should drink Coca-Cola for a living? No, I totally disagree with that," Brady said. "And when people do that, I think that's quackery. And the fact that they can sell that to kids? I mean, that's poison for kids." 
In response, Coca-Cola released a statement to Fox Business on Tuesday that said, "All of our beverages are safe and can be enjoyed as part of a balanced lifestyle." 
The company also added that they provide many drinking options for everyone. 
"We offer more than 200 low- and no-calorie beverages in the U.S. and Canada and a wide variety of smaller portion sizes of our regular drinks," the company said in a statement. "As a responsible beverage company and marketer, we prominently provide calorie and sugar information for our beverages so people can choose what makes sense for them and their families." 
Frosted Flakes also came under fire by Brady. The Patriots quarterback said that Tony the Tiger's cereal is part of the country's obesity problem. 
"You keep eating those things and you keep wondering why we do have just incredible rates of disease in our country," Brady said. 
Kellogg's took exception to that comment and said in a statement that cereal is associated with lower BMIs. 
"Cereal is a delicious and nutritious breakfast," a Kellogg spokesperson told Fox. "Numerous studies show that a cereal breakfast is associated with lower BMIs (body mass index)
